choices.text: The larynx ends at the level of the upper border of C7 vertebra
Laryngeal crepitus is a pathological finding and suggests cartilage inflammation
The larynx moves only vertically during phonation and swallowing
The larynx lies opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing neck palpation as part of a general ENT examination. During side-to-side manipulation of the laryngeal framework, the examiner notes a characteristic grating sensation. Which of the following statements about the anatomical position and mobility of the larynx is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)The larynx lies opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6

 

 

  • The larynx lies in front of the hypopharynx and extends from the level of the third to sixth cervical vertebrae, ending at the lower border of C6 in adults.
  • It moves vertically and in anteroposterior direction during phonation and swallowing.
  • The larynx can also be passively moved from side to side, producing a characteristic grating sensation known as laryngeal crepitus, which is a normal finding.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The larynx ends at the level of the upper border of C7 vertebra: Incorrect. The larynx ends at the lower border of C6, not C7.

 

Option B.Laryngeal crepitus is a pathological finding and suggests cartilage inflammation: Incorrect. Laryngeal crepitus is a normal physiological phenomenon, not pathological.

 

Option C. The larynx moves only vertically during phonation and swallowing: Incorrect. The larynx moves both vertically and anteroposteriorly, not just vertically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The larynx lies opposite C3–C6 vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6, exhibiting vertical, anteroposterior, and passive side-to-side movements including normal laryngeal crepitus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Arytenoid, cricoid, cuneiform
Corniculate, epiglottis, arytenoid
Arytenoid, corniculate, cuneiform
Thyroid, arytenoid, corniculate

questions.text: A 28-year-old man undergoes a laryngeal endoscopy for evaluation of hoarseness. During the examination, the ENT resident identifies the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, and is asked to name the paired cartilages of the larynx. Which of the following correctly lists the paired cartilages of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arytenoid, corniculate, cuneiform

 

 

  • The larynx consists of six cartilages: three unpaired (thyroid, cricoid, and epiglottis) and three paired (arytenoid, corniculate, and cuneiform).
  • The paired cartilages are located bilaterally and play key roles in vocal fold movement and airway protection.
  • The thyroid and cricoid cartilages are unpaired, while arytenoid, corniculate, and cuneiform cartilages are paired.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Arytenoid, cricoid, cuneiform: Incorrect. Cricoid is unpaired, so this is not a correct set of paired cartilages.
 

Option B. Corniculate, epiglottis, arytenoid: Incorrect. Epiglottis is unpaired, so this option is wrong.
 

Option D. Thyroid, arytenoid, corniculate: Incorrect. Thyroid is unpaired, so this combination is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The paired cartilages of the larynx are arytenoid, corniculate, and cuneiform, while thyroid, cricoid, and epiglottis are unpaired.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: The thyroid cartilage forms a 120° angle in males
The cricothyroid membrane lies above the thyroid cartilage and is used in cricothyrotomy
Most laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested below the vocal cords
Vocal cords are attached to the midpoint of the thyroid angle

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute upper airway obstruction following accidental aspiration of a foreign body. On examination, he is in severe respiratory distress and an emergent airway is needed. Which of the following statements about the thyroid cartilage and emergency airway access is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vocal cords are attached to the midpoint of the thyroid angle

 

 

  • The thyroid cartilage is the largest of all laryngeal cartilages.
  • It consists of two alae that join anteriorly to form an angle of 90° in males and 120° in females, giving rise to the laryngeal prominence or "Adam's apple."
  • The vocal cords attach to the midpoint of this thyroid angle.
  • Most foreign bodies in the larynx get arrested above the vocal cords, i.e., above the middle of the thyroid cartilage.
  • In airway emergencies, cricothyrotomy involves piercing the cricothyroid membrane, which lies below the thyroid cartilage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The thyroid cartilage forms a 120° angle in males: Incorrect. The angle is 90° in males, not 120°.
 

Option B.The cricothyroid membrane lies above the thyroid cartilage and is used in cricothyrotomy: Incorrect. The cricothyroid membrane lies below the thyroid cartilage, not above.
 

Option C.Most laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested below the vocal cords: Incorrect. Most foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, not below.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The vocal cords attach at the midpoint of the thyroid cartilage angle, and most laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above this level.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Thyroid cartilage forms a complete ring with an anterior arch and posterior lamina
Epiglottis has a complete ring-like structure and lies anterior to the vocal cords
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch
Arytenoid cartilage forms a complete ring and articulates directly with the thyroid cartilage

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is undergoing endoscopic examination of the larynx. The surgeon identifies a laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring and has a broad posterior part and a narrow anterior arch. Which of the following statements correctly describes this cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch

 

 

  • The cricoid cartilage is the only laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring.
  • Its posterior part is expanded and known as the lamina, while the anterior part is narrower and forms an arch.
  • This anatomical structure provides a critical support for the lower larynx and is important during procedures like tracheostomy and endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Thyroid cartilage forms a complete ring with an anterior arch and posterior lamina: Incorrect. The thyroid cartilage is open posteriorly and does not form a complete ring.
 

Option B .Epiglottis has a complete ring-like structure and lies anterior to the vocal cords: Incorrect. The epiglottis is a leaf-like structure that does not form a ring.
 

Option D. Arytenoid cartilage forms a complete ring and articulates directly with the thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. The arytenoid cartilage is paired and sits on the cricoid lamina but does not form a complete ring.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Cricoid cartilage is the only laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring, with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: The anterior surface of the epiglottis lies adjacent to the aryepiglottic folds
The pre-epiglottic space lies posterior to the epiglottis and contains lymph nodes
Mucosal pits and perforations in the epiglottis allow tumor spread into the pre-epiglottic space
The epiglottis is essential for swallowing and cannot be surgically removed without aspiration risk

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with carcinoma of the supraglottic larynx undergoes imaging, which reveals tumor invasion into the pre-epiglottic space. Which of the following anatomical features of the epiglottis is most relevant to this spread?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mucosal pits and perforations in the epiglottis allow tumor spread into the pre-epiglottic space

 

 

 

  • The epiglottis is a leaf-like elastic cartilage forming the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet.
  • It is connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament, dividing it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid parts.
  • A stalk-like petiole attaches the epiglottis to the thyroid angle, just above the vocal cord attachment.
  • Anterior surface is separated from the thyrohyoid membrane and thyroid cartilage by the pre-epiglottic space, a fat-filled potential space.
  • This space is commonly invaded by supraglottic and base of tongue cancers, often via perforations and mucosal pits in the epiglottis.
  • The tubercle of epiglottis, seen on the posterior surface, may obscure the anterior commissure during indirect laryngoscopy.
  • Though protective during swallowing, the epiglottis is not essential and may be amputated in cancer surgery with minimal aspiration risk.

 

Other Options:


Options A. The anterior surface of the epiglottis lies adjacent to the aryepiglottic folds: Incorrect. The anterior surface is separated by the pre-epiglottic space, not adjacent to aryepiglottic folds.
 

Options B. The pre-epiglottic space lies posterior to the epiglottis and contains lymph nodes: Incorrect. The pre-epiglottic space is anterior to the epiglottis and filled with fat, not lymph nodes.
 

Options D. The epiglottis is essential for swallowing and cannot be surgically removed without aspiration risk: Incorrect. The epiglottis can be amputated with little risk of aspiration, so it's not essential for swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mucosal pits and perforations in the epiglottis allow supraglottic carcinomas to spread into the pre-epiglottic space.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Corniculate cartilage provides attachment to intrinsic laryngeal muscles
Arytenoid cartilage apex supports the cuneiform cartilage
Cuneiform cartilage is rod-shaped and provides passive support to the aryepiglottic fold
Vocal cord is attached to the base of the arytenoid cartilage

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is undergoing microlaryngoscopy under general anesthesia. During the procedure, the surgeon identifies a pyramidal cartilage with an anteriorly directed vocal process and a lateral muscular process. Which of the following statements regarding laryngeal cartilages is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cuneiform cartilage is rod-shaped and provides passive support to the aryepiglottic fold

 

 

  • Arytenoid cartilages are paired and pyramidal in shape, with:
    • A base articulating with the cricoid cartilage
    • A muscular process (lateral), which provides attachment to intrinsic laryngeal muscles
    • A vocal process (anterior), giving attachment to the vocal cords
    • An apex, which supports the corniculate cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilages (of Santorini) are paired horn-like structures that sit on the apex of arytenoids.
  • Cuneiform cartilages (of Wrisberg) are rod-shaped, situated in the aryepiglottic folds in front of the corniculates, and provide passive structural support to the fold.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Corniculate cartilage provides attachment to intrinsic laryngeal muscles: Incorrect. Intrinsic laryngeal muscles attach to the muscular process of arytenoid, not to corniculate cartilage.
 

Option B.Arytenoid cartilage apex supports the cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. The apex of arytenoid supports the corniculate, not cuneiform cartilage.
 

Option D. Vocal cord is attached to the base of the arytenoid cartilage: Incorrect. The vocal cord attaches to the vocal process, not the base, of the arytenoid cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Cuneiform cartilages are rod-shaped, lie in the aryepiglottic fold, and provide passive support to the fold.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: The corniculate cartilage has undergone age-related hyaline ossification
The epiglottis is composed of hyaline cartilage and commonly ossifies with age
Hyaline cartilage ossification of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages can mimic foreign bodies
Aryepiglottic fold contains hyaline cartilage, which calcifies after age 25

questions.text: A 58-year-old man undergoes a lateral neck X-ray for evaluation of dysphagia. The radiologist notes calcified shadows near the larynx, but no clinical evidence of a foreign body is found. Which of the following best explains this radiological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline cartilage ossification of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages can mimic foreign bodies

 

 

 

  • Thyroid, cricoid, and most of the arytenoid cartilages are composed of hyaline cartilage, which can undergo ossification.
  • Ossification starts around age 25 in the thyroid cartilage, slightly later in the cricoid and arytenoids, and is complete by around 65 years.
  • This calcification may appear as dense shadows on X-rays, potentially being misinterpreted as foreign bodies in the esophagus or larynx.
  • In contrast, epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform, and the tip of the arytenoid (near the corniculate) are made of elastic fibrocartilage, which does not ossify like hyaline cartilage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The corniculate cartilage has undergone age-related hyaline ossification: Incorrect. Corniculate cartilage is elastic fibrocartilage and does not undergo ossification.
 

Option B. The epiglottis is composed of hyaline cartilage and commonly ossifies with age: Incorrect. Epiglottis is made of elastic fibrocartilage, not hyaline, and rarely ossifies.
 

Options D. Aryepiglottic fold contains hyaline cartilage, which calcifies after age 25: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic fold contains cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, which are elastic, not hyaline.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Ossification of hyaline cartilages like thyroid and cricoid can appear as calcifications on X-rays, potentially mimicking foreign bodies.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Cricoarytenoid joint is cartilaginous and allows only limited gliding movement
Cricothyroid joint is synovial and allows rotatory movement of arytenoid around a vertical axis
Cricoarytenoid joint allows both rotatory and gliding movements that control vocal cord position
Cricothyroid joint is formed by the petiole of epiglottis articulating with cricoid cartilage

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hoarseness of voice. On laryngeal examination and imaging, no vocal cord lesions are found. However, impaired mobility of the cricoarytenoid joint is suspected. Which of the following statements best describes the cricoarytenoid or cricothyroid joints?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricoarytenoid joint allows both rotatory and gliding movements that control vocal cord position

 

 

  • Cricoarytenoid joint is a synovial joint between the base of the arytenoid cartilage and a facet on the upper border of the cricoid lamina.
  • It allows two types of movements:
    • Rotatory, enabling abduction or adduction of the vocal cords
    • Gliding, in which the arytenoids move closer or further apart, thereby opening or closing the posterior glottis
  • Cricothyroid joint is also a synovial joint, formed between the inferior cornua of thyroid cartilage and a facet on cricoid cartilage.
  • Movement at the cricothyroid joint allows the cricoid to rotate around a transverse axis, modulating vocal cord tension.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricoarytenoid joint is cartilaginous and allows only limited gliding movement: Incorrect. Cricoarytenoid is a synovial (not cartilaginous) joint and allows both gliding and rotatory movement.
 

Option B. Cricothyroid joint is synovial and allows rotatory movement of arytenoid around a vertical axis: Incorrect. Rotatory movement of arytenoid cartilage occurs at the cricoarytenoid joint, not at the cricothyroid joint.
 

Option D. Cricothyroid joint is formed by the petiole of epiglottis articulating with cricoid cartilage: Incorrect. The petiole of the epiglottis does not form any joint; it attaches to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The cricoarytenoid joint allows both rotatory and gliding movements, enabling abduction/adduction of vocal cords and regulation of the glottic gap.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282, 283

choices.text: Cricotracheal membrane; intrinsic membrane connecting cricoid and trachea
Thyrohyoid membrane; extrinsic membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve
Hyoepiglottic ligament; intrinsic ligament anchoring epiglottis to thyroid cartilage
Thyrohyoid membrane; intrinsic membrane pierced by external laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is undergoing neck dissection for carcinoma of the larynx. During the procedure, the surgeon notes a membrane between the hyoid bone and thyroid cartilage, through which a nerve and vessels pass. Which of the following correctly identifies this structure and its classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyrohyoid membrane; extrinsic membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve

 

 

  • Extrinsic membranes and ligaments connect the larynx to structures outside it (e.g., hyoid bone or trachea).
  • The thyrohyoid membrane is an extrinsic membrane that connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone.
  • It is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve (branch of the superior laryngeal nerve) and superior laryngeal vessels.
  • Other extrinsic structures include:
    • Cricotracheal membrane (joins cricoid to first tracheal ring)
    • Hyoepiglottic ligament (joins epiglottis to hyoid bone
  • Intrinsic membranes, by contrast, remain within the larynx and do not connect to outside structures like the hyoid or trachea.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricotracheal membrane; intrinsic membrane connecting cricoid and trachea: Incorrect. Cricotracheal membrane is extrinsic, not intrinsic, and connects cricoid to trachea, not thyroid to hyoid.

Option C. Hyoepiglottic ligament; intrinsic ligament anchoring epiglottis to thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. Hyoepiglottic ligament is extrinsic and connects the epiglottis to the hyoid bone, not to thyroid cartilage.

Option D. Thyrohyoid membrane; intrinsic membrane pierced by external laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. The external laryngeal nerve does not pierce the thyrohyoid membrane; it's the internal laryngeal nerve that does.

 

Educational Objective:

The thyrohyoid membrane is an extrinsic laryngeal membrane connecting thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone and is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea
Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus
Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve
Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset respiratory distress after suspected inhalation of a small toy part. Imaging reveals the foreign body lodged in the subglottic region. Which of the following intrinsic laryngeal structures is most likely involved in the impaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus

 

 

  • The cricovocal membrane is a triangular fibroelastic structure considered an intrinsic membrane of the larynx.
  • Its upper free border stretches from the middle of the thyroid angle to the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage, forming the vocal ligament.
  • Its lower border is attached to the arch of the cricoid cartilage.
  • Together with its counterpart on the opposite side, it forms the conus elasticus, a cone-shaped membrane below the vocal cords.
  • Subglottic foreign bodies often get impacted in the conus elasticus, making it clinically significant in airway emergencies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea: Incorrect. Cricotracheal membrane is extrinsic and connects cricoid cartilage to the trachea; it’s not part of conus elasticus.

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. Thyrohyoid membrane is extrinsic and pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve; unrelated to subglottic obstruction.

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic fold is supraglottic, and not involved in subglottic foreign body impaction.

 

Educational Objective:


The cricovocal membrane forms the vocal ligament and, with its opposite side, forms the conus elasticus, where subglottic foreign bodies may get impacted.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Vestibular ligament; formed by the lower border of the quadrangular membrane
Cricothyroid ligament; forms the true vocal cord
Cricovocal membrane; forms the false vocal cord
Thyroepiglottic ligament; lies within the aryepiglottic fold and supports the false cord

questions.text: A 34-year-old male undergoes microlaryngoscopy. The surgeon identifies a ligament forming part of the false vocal cord and located within the aryepiglottic fold. Which of the following correctly identifies this ligament and its anatomical origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vestibular ligament; formed by the lower border of the quadrangular membrane

 

 

  • The quadrangular membrane is an intrinsic laryngeal membrane that lies deep to the mucosa of the aryepiglottic folds.
  • It extends between the epiglottic and arytenoid cartilages.
  • Its lower border forms the vestibular ligament, which lies within the false vocal cord (vestibular fold).
  • The cricothyroid ligament is the anterior thickened part of the cricothyroid membrane, while its lateral part forms the cricovocal membrane, which contributes to the true vocal cord.
  • The thyroepiglottic ligament attaches the epiglottis to the thyroid cartilage but does not form part of either vocal fold.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Cricothyroid ligament; forms the true vocal cord: Incorrect. Cricothyroid ligament contributes to the true vocal cord through its lateral part (cricovocal membrane), not the false cord.
 

Option C. Cricovocal membrane; forms the false vocal cord: Incorrect. Cricovocal membrane forms the true vocal ligament, not the false cord.
 

Option D. Thyroepiglottic ligament; lies within the aryepiglottic fold and supports the false cord: Incorrect. Thyroepiglottic ligament is a separate attachment structure and does not lie within the aryepiglottic fold.

 

Educational Objective:


The vestibular ligament is formed by the lower border of the quadrangular membrane and lies within the false vocal cord.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Cricovocal membrane forming the conus elasticus
Quadrangular membrane forming the vestibular fold
Saccule of the laryngeal ventricle giving rise to a laryngocele
Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage

questions.text: A 38-year-old professional singer presents with a compressible neck swelling that increases in size when blowing forcefully or straining. Laryngoscopy reveals a dilated air-filled sac extending from the larynx. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Saccule of the laryngeal ventricle giving rise to a laryngocele

 

 

  • The ventricle (sinus) of the larynx is a deep elliptical space between the vestibular (false) and vocal (true) folds.
  • The saccule is a mucosal diverticulum extending upward from the anterior part of the ventricle, between the vestibular fold and the lamina of thyroid cartilage.
  • It contains numerous mucous glands that help lubricate the vocal cords, especially important in voice professionals.
  • When the saccule becomes abnormally enlarged or distended, it forms a laryngocele—an air-filled sac that may present as a compressible neck swelling, especially prominent during straining or Valsalva.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricovocal membrane forming the conus elasticus: Incorrect. Cricovocal membrane forms part of the true vocal cord, not the laryngeal ventricle or saccule.

Option B. Quadrangular membrane forming the vestibular fold: Incorrect. The quadrangular membrane forms the vestibular ligament, not the ventricle or saccule.

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. The aryepiglottic fold houses cuneiform cartilage, but is not related to laryngocele formation.

 

Educational Objective:


The saccule is a mucosal extension of the laryngeal ventricle that may enlarge to form a laryngocele, often seen as a compressible neck swelling.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 284
