questions.text:
A 1st-year MBBS student is learning about the embryological development of laryngeal structures. Match the following laryngeal/cartilaginous structures with their corresponding pharyngeal arches:

 

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

Other Options :
 

From the given table:

 

  • Cricoid cartilage (1) arises from the 6th pharyngeal arch (D).
  • Lesser cornu of hyoid bone (2) comes from the 2nd arch (A).
  • Epiglottis (3) is derived from the hypobranchial eminence of the 4th arch (C).
  • Greater cornu and lower part of hyoid body (4) originate from the 3rd arch (B).

 

Other key derivations include:

 

  • Thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid, corniculate, and cuneiform cartilages — all from the 6th arch
  • Upper part of hyoid and lesser cornu — from 2nd arch
  • Lower hyoid and greater cornu — from 3rd arch

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal cartilages and hyoid bone structures develop from pharyngeal arches 2 to 6, with the epiglottis derived from the 4th arch (hypobranchial eminence) and cricoid cartilage from the 6th arch.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Spasmodic dysphonia
Functional ventricular dysphonia
Vocal cord nodules
Reinke’s edema

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rough, low-pitched, and unpleasant voice. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals that her false vocal cords are approximating and obscuring the view of true cords during phonation. There is no paralysis or lesion of the true vocal cords. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional ventricular dysphonia

 

 

  • Ventricular dysphonia (dysphonia plica ventricularis) occurs when the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) begin to take over the phonatory function normally carried out by the true vocal cords. 
  • This results in a rough, low-pitched, unpleasant voice.
  • Two forms exist:
    • Secondary type: Occurs when the true cords are impaired (e.g., due to paralysis, surgery, fixation, or tumor), and ventricular bands compensate.
    • Functional type: Occurs in a normal larynx, often psychogenic. Voice starts normally but becomes rough when false cords usurp function.
  • On indirect laryngoscopy, the false cords approximate partially or completely, obscuring the view of true cords.
  • Functional cases respond well to voice therapy and psychological counselling, whereas secondary types are more difficult to treat.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Spasmodic dysphonia: Incorrect. Spasmodic dysphonia is a neurological voice disorder with voice breaks and strain, not caused by false cord phonation.
 

Option C. Vocal cord nodules: Incorrect. Vocal cord nodules are located on true cords and result in hoarseness, not false cord phonation.

 


Option D. Reinke’s edema: Incorrect. Reinke’s edema causes swelling of the true cords, not false cord compensation.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

In functional ventricular dysphonia, false vocal cords take over phonation, leading to rough voice despite a normal larynx, and is treatable with voice therapy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 313, 314

choices.text: Cricothyrotomy involves vertical incision of the cricothyroid membrane followed by insertion of an endotracheal tube
Cricothyroidotomy provides long-term airway support and prevents laryngeal stenosis
Mini tracheostomy is an elective procedure commonly used to replace prolonged endotracheal intubation
Cricothyroid needle puncture allows temporary oxygenation but is not a definitive airway

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe upper airway obstruction following facial trauma. The team decides to perform an emergency airway procedure by accessing the cricothyroid membrane. Which of the following statements about this procedure is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cricothyroid needle puncture allows temporary oxygenation but is not a definitive airway

 

 

  • Cricothyrotomy (also called laryngotomy or mini tracheostomy) is a life-saving emergency procedure to establish an airway via the cricothyroid membrane.
  • The patient’s neck is extended, and a vertical skin incision is followed by a transverse cut through the cricothyroid membrane.
  • If no tube is available, even the knife handle can be rotated at right angles to keep the airway open.
  • This is a temporary measure and should be followed by a proper tracheostomy to avoid complications like perichondritis, subglottic edema, and laryngeal stenosis.
  • Mini tracheostomy is often done in emergencies to buy time until a definitive airway can be secured.
  • Cricothyroid needle puncture (using a large-bore IV catheter) is only a temporary method of oxygenation, and does not provide adequate ventilation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricothyrotomy involves vertical incision of the cricothyroid membrane followed by insertion of an endotracheal tube: Incorrect. The membrane is cut transversely, but vertical incision refers to the skin. Also, it is not always followed by an endotracheal tube but may use a mini trach tube.
 

Option B. Cricothyroidotomy provides long-term airway support and prevents laryngeal stenosis: Incorrect. Prolonged cricothyrotomy can actually cause laryngeal stenosis; hence it's not suitable for long-term use.
 

Option C. Mini tracheostomy is an elective procedure commonly used to replace prolonged endotracheal intubation: Incorrect. Mini tracheostomy is primarily an emergency airway access, though it may be done electively in post-thoracic surgery cases to clear secretions, not for long-term airway replacement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Cricothyroid needle puncture is a temporary emergency procedure for oxygenation but does not provide adequate ventilation and must be followed by a definitive airway.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 320

choices.text: Branchial cyst
Thyroglossal cyst
Laryngocele
Laryngeal papilloma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male trumpet player presents with hoarseness and a swelling in the neck that increases on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On examination, the swelling is soft, compressible, and reducible. Indirect laryngoscopy shows bulging of the false vocal cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngocele

 

  • A laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling resulting from the dilatation of the laryngeal saccule, commonly seen in individuals with repeated raised transglottic pressure (e.g., trumpet players, glass-blowers, weightlifters).
  • It may be:
    • Internal, confined to the larynx, bulging into the false vocal cord or aryepiglottic fold
    • External, herniating through the thyrohyoid membrane, presenting as a reducible neck swelling
    • Mixed, with both internal and external components
  • Symptoms include hoarseness, cough, and in large lesions, airway obstruction.
  • Diagnosis is made by indirect laryngoscopy, X-rays with Valsalva, and CT scan to assess extent. 
  • Treatment:
    • External excision for external/mixed types
    • Marsupialization via laryngoscopy for internal types (but with risk of recurrence)
  • In adults, laryngocele may be secondary to carcinoma, due to obstruction of the saccule.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Branchial cyst: Incorrect. Branchial cyst is a congenital neck mass, typically not reducible or influenced by Valsalva.

 


Option B. Thyroglossal cyst: Incorrect. Thyroglossal cyst moves with swallowing/tongue protrusion, and not related to false cords or air pressure.

 


Option D. Laryngeal papilloma: Incorrect. Laryngeal papilloma causes hoarseness but not neck swelling or reducible mass.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Laryngocele is an air-filled saccular dilatation presenting with hoarseness and neck swelling that increases with Valsalva, commonly seen in patients with raised transglottic pressure.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 305

choices.text: Broyle’s ligament
Cricothyroid ligament
Aryepiglottic fold
Vestibular fold

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a laryngeal injury after a motor vehicle accident. He has hoarseness of voice and mild anterior neck swelling. Imaging shows disruption near the anterior commissure of the vocal cords. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Broyle’s ligament

 

 

  • The thyroid cartilage is the largest laryngeal cartilage and forms the Adam’s apple, which is more prominent in males due to a sharper 90° angle (vs. 120° in females).
  • It is connected superiorly to the hyoid bone by the thyrohyoid membrane, which has openings bilaterally for passage of the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve into the larynx.
  • The vocal ligaments originate from the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages and insert anteriorly into the thyroid cartilage at the anterior commissure via Broyle’s ligament.
  • Injury at the anterior commissure, especially from trauma, commonly involves Broyle’s ligament, affecting vocal cord attachment and function.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Cricothyroid ligament: Incorrect. The cricothyroid ligament lies below the vocal cords and is involved in emergency airway access (e.g., cricothyrotomy), not vocal cord attachment.

 


Option C. Aryepiglottic fold: Incorrect. The aryepiglottic fold forms the lateral boundary of the laryngeal inlet and is not involved in vocal ligament attachment.

 


Option D. Vestibular fold: Incorrect. The vestibular fold contributes to the false vocal cord (vestibular ligament), not the true cord or anterior commissure.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The vocal cords attach to the thyroid cartilage at the anterior commissure via Broyle’s ligament, which may be disrupted in laryngeal trauma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg  282

choices.text: Paraglottic space
Pre-epiglottic space
Retropharyngeal space
Pyriform sinus

questions.text: A 62-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness and dysphagia. On flexible laryngoscopy, a mass is seen involving the supraglottic region, with suspicion of deeper tissue invasion. Which anatomical space is most likely involved in the early spread of this malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pre-epiglottic space

 

 

  • The epiglottis is a single leaf-shaped elastic cartilage, attached posteriorly to the thyroid cartilage by the thyroepiglottic ligament and superiorly to the hyoid bone via the hyoepiglottic ligament.
  • The pre-epiglottic space (of Boyer) is a triangular fat-filled space bordered:
    • Anteriorly by the thyrohyoid membrane
    • Posteriorly by the epiglottis
    • Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament
  • It is a key site for early cancer spread in malignancies of the supraglottis or base of tongue, particularly due to pits in the epiglottic surface that allow direct tumor invasion.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Paraglottic space: Incorrect. Paraglottic space lies lateral to the vocal cords and is more involved in glottic or subglottic spread.

 


Option C. Retropharyngeal space: Incorrect. Retropharyngeal space lies posterior to the pharynx and is not directly involved in supraglottic cancer spread.

 


Option D. Pyriform sinus: Incorrect. Pyriform sinus (PFS) is a part of the hypopharynx, and while it may be secondarily involved, it is not the first site of invasion from epiglottic tumors.

 

 

Educational Objective:


The pre-epiglottic space, bounded by epiglottis, thyrohyoid membrane, and hyoepiglottic ligament, is commonly involved in early spread of supraglottic or base of tongue cancers.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Cricoid cartilage is incomplete posteriorly, allowing for arytenoid movement
Cricothyroid joint is formed between cricoid lamina and superior horn of thyroid cartilage
Cricothyroid muscle originates from thyroid cartilage and inserts into cricoid
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a thin anterior arch and broad posterior lamina

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing evaluation for progressive voice fatigue. Laryngeal examination and imaging reveal tension alteration in the vocal cords without any lesion. Dysfunction of the cricothyroid joint is suspected. Which of the following statements regarding the cricoid cartilage and its related anatomy is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a thin anterior arch and broad posterior lamina

 

 

  • The cricoid cartilage is the only complete ring among the laryngeal cartilages.
  • Anteriorly, it is thin and forms the arch; posteriorly, it expands into a broad plate called the lamina.
  • The cricothyroid joint is formed at the posterolateral aspect of the cricoid where it articulates with the inferior cornu of the thyroid cartilage.
  • The cricothyroid muscle originates from the cricoid cartilage and inserts into the thyroid cartilage—it controls tension of the vocal cords by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricoid cartilage is incomplete posteriorly, allowing for arytenoid movement: Incorrect. Cricoid cartilage is complete posteriorly; it is the only complete ring, and the arytenoids sit on top of the cricoid lamina.
 

Option B. Cricothyroid joint is formed between cricoid lamina and superior horn of thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. The cricothyroid joint is formed by the inferior cornu of the thyroid, not the superior horn.

 


Option C. Cricothyroid muscle originates from thyroid cartilage and inserts into cricoid: Incorrect. The cricothyroid muscle originates from the cricoid, not thyroid.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a thin anterior arch and broad posterior lamina, and articulates with the thyroid cartilage at the cricothyroid joint.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Damage to the cuneiform cartilage impairs vocal fold abduction
Disruption of the cricoarytenoid joint affects gliding and rotatory movement of arytenoid cartilages
Injury to the vocal process prevents attachment of intrinsic laryngeal muscles
Displacement of the thyroid cartilage leads to fixation of the corniculate cartilage

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with hoarseness and difficulty breathing following prolonged intubation. Laryngoscopic examination reveals immobility of the vocal cords due to posterior cricoarytenoid muscle dysfunction. Which of the following best explains the anatomical basis of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Disruption of the cricoarytenoid joint affects gliding and rotatory movement of arytenoid cartilages

 

 

  • Arytenoid cartilages sit on the posterior lamina of the cricoid cartilage, forming a synovial cricoarytenoid joint.
  • Each arytenoid has:
    • An anterior vocal process – attachment site for vocal ligament
    • A posterolateral muscular process – attachment site for intrinsic laryngeal muscles (e.g., posterior cricoarytenoid)
  • The cricoarytenoid joint allows two movements:
    • Rotatory – to abduct/adduct vocal cords
    • Gliding – to approximate or separate the arytenoids
  • Prolonged intubation can lead to joint fibrosis or fixation, resulting in vocal cord immobility and hoarseness.
  • Corniculate cartilages lie on top of arytenoid apices, and cuneiform cartilages lie above them in the aryepiglottic fold, but they don’t contribute to vocal cord movement.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Damage to the cuneiform cartilage impairs vocal fold abduction: Incorrect. Cuneiform cartilage is non-articulating and does not affect vocal cord movement.
 

Option C. Injury to the vocal process prevents attachment of intrinsic laryngeal muscles: Incorrect. The vocal process is the attachment point for the vocal ligament, not muscles. Muscles attach to the muscular process.
 

Option D. Displacement of the thyroid cartilage leads to fixation of the corniculate cartilage: Incorrect. Thyroid cartilage displacement does not directly affect corniculate or arytenoid movement at the cricoarytenoid joint.

 

Educational Objective:


The cricoarytenoid joint enables gliding and rotatory movement of the arytenoids, essential for vocal cord motion; joint dysfunction can lead to hoarseness and airway issues.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Ossification of elastic cartilages including corniculate and cuneiform cartilages
Calcification of thyroid and cricoid cartilages, which are hyaline and undergo ossification with age
Radiopaque foreign bodies lodged in the epiglottic vallecula
Dystrophic calcification of the vocal ligaments due to vocal strain

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with sudden onset dysphagia. A lateral neck X-ray is performed to rule out a foreign body. The radiologist notes calcified densities in the laryngeal region but no clinical signs of obstruction are found. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification of thyroid and cricoid cartilages, which are hyaline and undergo ossification with age

 

 

  • The thyroid, cricoid, and most of the arytenoid cartilages are hyaline cartilage, which undergo ossification later in life, especially in the elderly.
  • This ossification can appear as calcified shadows on X-ray, sometimes mimicking foreign bodies, especially in elderly patients.
  • In contrast, the epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform, and the apex of the arytenoid are composed of elastic cartilage, which does not ossify.
  • Recognizing this distinction is crucial to avoid misdiagnosis of foreign bodies in elderly patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Ossification of elastic cartilages including corniculate and cuneiform cartilages: Incorrect. Elastic cartilages (e.g., corniculate, cuneiform) do not ossify, so they don’t cause such calcified appearances.
 

Option C. Radiopaque foreign bodies lodged in the epiglottic vallecula: Incorrect. There is no foreign body present clinically or on examination; this is a physiological ossification, not a lodged object.
 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification of the vocal ligaments due to vocal strain: Incorrect. Vocal ligaments are fibroelastic tissue, not cartilage, and do not undergo dystrophic calcification from strain.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Hyaline cartilages like thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid undergo age-related ossification, which can mimic foreign bodies on radiographs in elderly patients.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Cricovocal membrane enclosing the glottic and subglottic areas
Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve
Quadrangular membrane enclosing the supraglottic airway
Pre-epiglottic ligament anchoring epiglottis to hyoid bone

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoes evaluation for mild hoarseness. On fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the supraglottic area appears structurally intact with normal mucosa and preserved airway lumen. The ENT specialist explains that a key membrane enclosing the supraglottic airway extends from the epiglottis to the arytenoids and forms part of the laryngeal framework. Which of the following best describes this membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quadrangular membrane (AEF) enclosing the supraglottic airway

 

 

  • The quadrangular membrane is an intrinsic fibroelastic membrane of the larynx.
  • It extends from the epiglottis anteriorly (above) to the arytenoid cartilages posteriorly (below).
  • This membrane forms the lateral wall of the supraglottic larynx and plays a key role in maintaining the airway’s contour.
  • It encloses the airway lumen in the supraglottic region, and is supported by associated muscles, contributing to its structural integrity.
  • The lower free border of the quadrangular membrane forms the vestibular ligament, which lies within the false vocal cord.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricovocal membrane enclosing the glottic and subglottic areas: Incorrect. Cricovocal membrane lies below the vocal cords, in the glottic and subglottic region, and contributes to conus elasticus.

 


Option B. Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. Thyrohyoid membrane is an extrinsic membrane and lies external to the larynx, not forming the airway wall.

 


Option D. Pre-epiglottic ligament anchoring epiglottis to hyoid bone: Incorrect. There is no structure called pre-epiglottic ligament; possibly a confusion with the hyoepiglottic ligament, which anchors the epiglottis but does not enclose the airway.

 

Educational Objective:


The quadrangular membrane extends from the epiglottis to the arytenoids and forms part of the supraglottic airway wall.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Enlargement of the ventricle lying above the true vocal cords
Distension of the saccule extending from the laryngeal ventricle
Hypertrophy of the vocal ligament within the true vocal cords
Gliding of the arytenoid cartilages at the cricoarytenoid joint

questions.text: A 38-year-old professional glass - blower presents with hoarseness and a soft, reducible swelling in the neck that increases with coughing or straining. On laryngoscopic examination, a bulge is noted between the false and true vocal cords. Which of the following best explains the underlying anatomical structure involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distension of the saccule extending from the laryngeal ventricle

 

 

  • The quadrangular membrane forms the false vocal cords (also called vestibular or ventricular folds) via its lower thickened border.
  • The space between the false cords above and the true vocal cords below is known as the laryngeal ventricle.
  • From the anterior part of this ventricle, a mucosal-lined pouch called the saccule extends upward.
  • The saccule contains mucous glands, which lubricate the true vocal cords (important for phonation).
  • In individuals with increased transglottic air pressure (e.g., glass-blowers, wind instrument players), the saccule can become distended, forming an air-filled laryngocele.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Enlargement of the ventricle lying above the true vocal cords: Incorrect. The ventricle itself is a space, but it is the saccule (a diverticulum from it) that gets distended.

 


Option C. Hypertrophy of the vocal ligament within the true vocal cords: Incorrect. The vocal ligament is part of the true vocal cords, and its hypertrophy does not lead to laryngocele.

 


Option D. Gliding of the arytenoid cartilages at the cricoarytenoid joint: Incorrect. Arytenoid movement at the cricoarytenoid joint controls vocal cord motion, not saccule distension.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Laryngocele results from distension of the laryngeal saccule, which extends from the ventricle between false and true vocal cords and provides secretions for vocal cord lubrication.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

choices.text: Spasmodic dysphonia due to laryngeal muscle spasm
Vocal cord polyp causing turbulent vibration of true cords
Dysphonia plica ventricularis due to phonation by false vocal cords
Functional aphonia caused by complete loss of cord movement

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with a rough, low-pitched, and unpleasant voice. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals that her false vocal cords are approximating during phonation, while the true vocal cords are not effectively vibrating. Which of the following best describes this voice disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dysphonia plica ventricularis due to phonation by false vocal cords

 

 

  • Normal voice production involves approximation and vibration of the true vocal cords.
  • In dysphonia plica ventricularis (also called ventricular dysphonia), the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) come together and vibrate abnormally, attempting to produce sound.
  • This results in a harsh, low-pitched, and strained voice that is unpleasant and often inefficient for speech.
  • It may occur:
    • Secondarily, when true vocal cords are paralyzed, fixed, or resected
    • Or as a functional/psychogenic disorder, even with normal anatomy
  • Laryngoscopy confirms the false cord approximation instead of true cord vibration during phonation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Spasmodic dysphonia due to laryngeal muscle spasm: Incorrect. Spasmodic dysphonia involves involuntary spasms of laryngeal muscles, not false cord vibration.
 

Option B. Vocal cord polyp causing turbulent vibration of true cords: Incorrect. Vocal cord polyps affect the true cords and cause hoarseness due to turbulent airflow, not false cord phonation.

 


Option D. Functional aphonia caused by complete loss of cord movement: Incorrect. Functional aphonia involves no voice production due to lack of cord movement, not false cord vibration.

 

Educational Objective:


Dysphonia plica ventricularis occurs when voice is produced by approximation of false vocal cords instead of true vocal cords.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 313

choices.text: Quadrangular membrane forming the supraglottic false cords
Cricovocal membrane forming conus elasticus and true vocal support
Pretracheal fascia enclosing the thyroid gland and strap muscles
Aryepiglottic fold providing lateral boundary of laryngeal inlet

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe upper airway obstruction. While preparing for a formal tracheostomy, the team decides to perform an emergency airway procedure through the cricothyroid membrane. Which of the following anatomical structures is involved in this intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricovocal membrane forming conus elasticus and true vocal support

 

  • The cricovocal membrane is part of the intrinsic laryngeal framework, located between the cricoid cartilage below and the vocal ligament above.
  • On both sides, it continues to form the conus elasticus, which funnels air toward the glottis and supports the true vocal cords.
  • The anterior thickened part of this membrane is called the cricothyroid membrane.
  • This site is used in cricothyrotomy (or cricothyroidotomy), an emergency airway procedure performed when tracheostomy is not immediately feasible.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Quadrangular membrane forming the supraglottic false cords: Incorrect. The quadrangular membrane contributes to the false vocal cords (vestibular folds), not involved in airway access.
 

Option C. Pretracheal fascia enclosing the thyroid gland and strap muscles: Incorrect. The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland and anterior neck muscles but is not the target site for emergency airway access.
 

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold providing lateral boundary of laryngeal inlet: Incorrect. The aryepiglottic fold forms part of the laryngeal inlet, not related to conus elasticus or cricothyrotomy.

 

Educational Objective:


The cricovocal membrane forms conus elasticus and its anterior thickened part (cricothyroid membrane) is the site for emergency cricothyrotomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 320

choices.text: Branchial cleft cyst
Internal laryngocele
Mixed laryngocele
Laryngeal papilloma

questions.text: A 42-year-old professional trumpet player presents with hoarseness and a soft, compressible swelling on the side of his neck that increases with coughing and straining. On compression, a hissing sound is heard, and the swelling reduces. Laryngoscopy shows bulging of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed laryngocele

 

 

  • A laryngocele is an air-filled cystic dilatation of the laryngeal saccule, which may occur due to repeated raised intralaryngeal pressure, commonly seen in glass-blowers, trumpet players, etc.
  • It has 3 types:
    • Internal: Confined to the larynx, presents as bulging of the false vocal cord and aryepiglottic fold (AEF)
    • External: Confined to the neck, herniates through thyrohyoid membrane, and presents as a soft neck swelling that increases with Valsalva
    • Mixed: Has both internal and external components—seen when the dilated saccule expands further through the thyrohyoid membrane, producing both laryngeal and external neck findings
  • The Bryce sign (hissing sound heard when the neck swelling is compressed and air escapes into the larynx) is characteristic.
  • Treatment involves surgical excision or marsupialization (especially for internal lesions).

 

Other Options:


Option A. Branchial cleft cyst: Incorrect. Branchial cleft cysts are non-air-filled congenital lesions and do not change in size with Valsalva or produce a hissing sound.
 

Option B. Internal laryngocele: Incorrect. Internal laryngocele would not present with external neck swelling.
 

Option D. Laryngeal papilloma: Incorrect. Laryngeal papillomas are mucosal growths on the vocal cords, not air-filled and non-compressible.

 

Educational Objective:


A mixed laryngocele presents with both internal laryngeal and external neck components and is characterized by a compressible swelling with Bryce sign.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

choices.text: Free margin of the epiglottis
Aryepiglottic folds
Interarytenoid fold
Vocal ligaments

questions.text: A 32-year-old man undergoes fiberoptic laryngoscopy as part of pre-operative assessment. The ENT surgeon points out the anatomical boundaries of the laryngeal inlet. Which of the following structures forms the posterior boundary of the laryngeal inlet?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interarytenoid fold

 

 

  • The inlet of the larynx is an oblique opening at the top of the larynx that communicates with the pharynx.
  • It is bounded by:
    • Anteriorly: the free margin of the epiglottis
    • Laterally: the aryepiglottic folds, which extend from the epiglottis to the arytenoids
    • Posteriorly: the interarytenoid fold, formed by the mucosa covering the interarytenoid musculature connecting both arytenoids
  • This inlet serves as the gateway to the lower airway, and its closure is essential during swallowing to prevent aspiration.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Free margin of the epiglottis: Incorrect. The free margin of the epiglottis forms the anterior boundary, not posterior.

 

Option B. Aryepiglottic folds: Incorrect. The aryepiglottic folds form the lateral boundaries.

 


Option D. Vocal ligaments: Incorrect. The vocal ligaments are located below the laryngeal inlet, within the glottis region.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The posterior boundary of the laryngeal inlet is formed by the interarytenoid fold, while the anterior and lateral boundaries are formed by the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds, respectively.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 284

choices.text: Posterior surface of the epiglottis
Aryepiglottic folds
Anterior surface of the arytenoid cartilages
Interarytenoid fold

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is undergoing a fiberoptic laryngoscopic exam for evaluation of voice changes. The examiner describes the vestibule of the larynx and points out its anatomical boundaries. Which of the following correctly describes the posterior wall of the laryngeal vestibule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior surface of the arytenoid cartilages

 

 

  • The laryngeal vestibule is the upper part of the laryngeal cavity, extending from the laryngeal inlet above to the vestibular (false vocal) folds below.
  • Its boundaries are:
    • Anterior wall: Posterior surface of the epiglottis
    • Lateral walls: Aryepiglottic folds, which stretch from the epiglottis to the arytenoid cartilages
    • Posterior wall: Formed by the mucosa over the anterior surface of the arytenoid cartilages
  • This area is important in airway protection during swallowing and phonation.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Posterior surface of the epiglottis: Incorrect. The posterior surface of the epiglottis forms the anterior wall, not posterior.
 

Option B. Aryepiglottic folds: Incorrect. The aryepiglottic folds form the lateral walls.
 

Option D. Interarytenoid fold: Incorrect. The interarytenoid fold lies above the arytenoids, forming the posterior boundary of the inlet, not the vestibule.

 

Educational Objective:


The vestibule of the larynx extends from the inlet to the vestibular folds and is bounded posteriorly by the anterior surface of the arytenoid cartilages.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: From laryngeal inlet to the vestibular folds
From vestibular folds to the vocal cords
From vocal cords to lower border of cricoid cartilage
From vocal cords to the first tracheal ring

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with stridor and barking cough. A lateral neck X-ray shows narrowing just below the vocal cords. The ENT specialist diagnoses subglottic laryngitis (croup). Which of the following best describes the anatomical extent of the subglottic space?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) From vocal cords to lower border of cricoid cartilage 

 

 

  • The subglottic space (also called infraglottic larynx) extends from the level of the vocal cords to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage.
  • It represents the narrowest part of the airway in children, which makes it clinically significant in conditions like croup, post-intubation stenosis, or subglottic hemangiomas.
  • Below the cricoid cartilage, the airway continues as the trachea.

 

Other Options:


Option A. From laryngeal inlet to the vestibular folds: Incorrect. This describes the supraglottis, not the subglottic space.
 

Option B. From vestibular folds to the vocal cords: Incorrect. This refers to the glottis and part of the ventricle, not the subglottic region.
 

Option D. From vocal cords to the first tracheal ring: Incorrect. The subglottic space ends at the lower border of cricoid cartilage, not the first tracheal ring.

 

Educational Objective:


The subglottic space extends from the vocal cords to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage and is clinically relevant in pediatric airway obstruction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: The space between the vestibular folds and the epiglottis
The space between the vocal cords and the aryepiglottic folds
The space between the vocal cords anteriorly and the arytenoid vocal processes posteriorly
The space between the vocal cords and the tracheal rings

questions.text: A 27-year-old singer presents with sudden loss of voice. Laryngoscopic examination reveals a structural issue involving the space between the vocal cords. Which of the following correctly defines the glottis (rima glottidis)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The space between the vocal cords anteriorly and the arytenoid vocal processes posteriorly

 

 

  • The glottis (rima glottidis) is the narrowest part of the adult larynx and plays a key role in phonation and airway protection.
  • It is the elongated space between:
    • Vocal cords anteriorly
    • Vocal processes and base of arytenoid cartilages posteriorly
  • During phonation, the glottis closes as vocal cords approximate; during breathing, it opens.
  • Pathologies involving the glottis can cause hoarseness, voice fatigue, or aspiration risk.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The space between the vestibular folds and the epiglottis: Incorrect. This refers to part of the laryngeal vestibule, not the glottis.

Option B. The space between the vocal cords and the aryepiglottic folds: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic folds are lateral to the laryngeal inlet, not part of the glottis.
 

Option D. The space between the vocal cords and the tracheal rings: Incorrect. This area lies below the glottis in the subglottic region.

 

Educational Objective:


The glottis (rima glottidis) is the space between the vocal cords anteriorly and the vocal processes/base of arytenoids posteriorly.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: The entire glottis is formed by cartilaginous vocal processes of the arytenoids
The glottis is wider in women (24 mm) than in men (16 mm)
The anterior two-thirds of the glottis is involved primarily in phonation
The glottis remains constant in size during respiration and phonation

questions.text: A 35-year-old male professional voice artist undergoes laryngoscopy for evaluation of vocal fatigue. The ENT specialist explains the structure and function of the glottis. Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy and function of the glottis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The anterior two-thirds of the glottis is involved primarily in phonation

 

 

  • The glottis is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity and plays a vital role in phonation and respiration.
  • Anteroposterior length of the glottis is approximately 24 mm in men and 16 mm in women.
  • The anterior two-thirds of the glottis is formed by the membranous vocal cords and is referred to as the phonatory glottis, as it vibrates during speech.
  • The posterior one-third is formed by the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages and is called the respiratory glottis, important in maintaining an open airway.
  • The size and shape of the glottis changes with vocal cord movement—open during breathing, closed during phonation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The entire glottis is formed by cartilaginous vocal processes of the arytenoids: Incorrect. Only the posterior one-third is cartilaginous; the anterior two-thirds is membranous.

Option B. The glottis is wider in women (24 mm) than in men (16 mm): Incorrect. Glottis is longer in men (24 mm) than in women (16 mm).

Option D. The glottis remains constant in size during respiration and phonation: Incorrect. The glottis does not remain constant; it changes during breathing and phonation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior two-thirds of the glottis is the phonatory glottis (membranous), while the posterior one-third is the respiratory glottis (cartilaginous), with the glottis being the narrowest part of the larynx.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Vocal cords are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with sparse mucous glands
The stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords lacks mucous glands
The saccules of the larynx drain into the vocal cords and maintain their moisture
Corniculate and cuneiform cartilages have abundant mucous glands that supply the vocal cords

questions.text: A 40-year-old male singer presents with persistent hoarseness. On laryngoscopic examination, the vocal cords appear dry and lack the usual glistening surface seen elsewhere in the larynx. Which of the following best explains the anatomical basis for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords lacks mucous glands

 

 

  • The mucous membrane of the larynx is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium, except in areas exposed to mechanical stress—namely, the true vocal cords and upper part of the vestibule, which are lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • The true vocal cords are tightly bound and contain no mucous glands, making them vulnerable to dryness and irritation, especially in professional voice users.
  • Mucous glands are abundant in areas such as the posterior surface of the epiglottis, posterior part of aryepiglottic folds, and the laryngeal saccules, but these do not directly lubricate the true vocal cords.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vocal cords are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with sparse mucous glands: Incorrect. Vocal cords are not lined by ciliated columnar epithelium and lack mucous glands.

 


Option C. The saccules of the larynx drain into the vocal cords and maintain their moisture: Incorrect. While saccules produce mucus, their secretions do not directly drain into the vocal cords.
 

Option D. Corniculate and cuneiform cartilages have abundant mucous glands that supply the vocal cords: Incorrect. Corniculate and cuneiform cartilages are covered by mucosa, but do not supply the vocal cords with mucus.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The true vocal cords are lined by stratified squamous epithelium and lack mucous glands, predisposing them to dryness and vocal fatigue.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: The vocal cords have abundant lymphatic supply that drains to upper cervical nodes
The cricothyroid membrane prevents lymphatic spread from the vocal cords
The vocal cords lack significant lymphatic drainage, reducing chances of metastasis
Lymphatic drainage from the vocal cords is directed only to mediastinal nodes

questions.text: A 62-year-old male smoker is diagnosed with carcinoma of the vocal cords. Imaging reveals no evidence of lymph node metastasis. Which of the following best explains the absence of lymphatic spread in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The vocal cords lack significant lymphatic drainage, reducing chances of metastasis

 

  • The lymphatic drainage of the larynx varies by region:
    • Supraglottic larynx (above vocal cords): drains through the thyrohyoid membrane to upper deep cervical nodes
    • Infraglottic larynx (below vocal cords): drains through cricothyroid and cricotracheal membranes to prelaryngeal, pretracheal, lower deep cervical, and mediastinal nodes
  • The true vocal cords themselves have very few or no lymphatic vessels, making lymphatic spread of carcinoma rare when confined to this region.

  • This explains the favorable prognosis and lower risk of nodal metastasis in early-stage glottic cancers.

     

 

Other Options:


Option A. The vocal cords have abundant lymphatic supply that drains to upper cervical nodes: Incorrect. Vocal cords lack abundant lymphatic supply, unlike the supraglottic region.

Option B. The cricothyroid membrane prevents lymphatic spread from the vocal cords: Incorrect. The cricothyroid membrane is related to infraglottic drainage, not a barrier to vocal cord metastasis.

Option D. Lymphatic drainage from the vocal cords is directed only to mediastinal nodes: Incorrect. The vocal cords do not drain to mediastinal nodes directly; the infraglottic region may.

 

Educational Objective:


The vocal cords have minimal lymphatic drainage, which is why carcinomas limited to this region rarely metastasize via lymphatics.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Paraglottic space, bounded anteriorly by hyoid bone and posteriorly by cricoid cartilage
Retropharyngeal space, extending between buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia
Pre-epiglottic space of Boyer, bounded anteriorly by thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
Vallecula, located between base of tongue and posterior epiglottis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with supraglottic carcinoma undergoes imaging to assess local spread. The tumor is found to have extended into a fat-filled space between the epiglottis and the thyroid cartilage. Which of the following best describes this anatomical space and its boundaries?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-epiglottic space of Boyer, bounded anteriorly by thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane

 

 

  • The pre-epiglottic space of Boyer is a clinically important fat-filled space located anterior to the epiglottis, and it is often involved in supraglottic cancers.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anteriorly: Upper part of thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
    • Superiorly: Hyoepiglottic ligament
    • Posteriorly: Infrahyoid part of the epiglottis and quadrangular membrane
    • Laterally: Continuous with the paraglottic space
  • It contains fat, areolar tissue, and lymphatics, and tumor spread into this space has prognostic implications in laryngeal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Paraglottic space, bounded anteriorly by hyoid bone and posteriorly by cricoid cartilage: Incorrect. The paraglottic space lies lateral to the laryngeal ventricle, not between the epiglottis and thyroid cartilage.

 


Option B. Retropharyngeal space, extending between buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia: Incorrect. The retropharyngeal space is located posterior to the pharynx and is unrelated to the epiglottis or thyroid cartilage.
 

Option D. Vallecula, located between base of tongue and posterior epiglottis: Incorrect. The vallecula lies between the tongue base and epiglottis, not anterior to the epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective:


The pre-epiglottic space of Boyer lies between the epiglottis and thyroid cartilage, and is a common site of tumor spread in supraglottic laryngeal cancers.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Pre-epiglottic space; bounded laterally by pyriform sinus and medially by epiglottis
Paraglottic space; bounded laterally by thyroid cartilage and medially by quadrangular membrane
Retropharyngeal space; located posterior to pharynx and thyroid cartilage
Infraglottic space; bounded superiorly by the vocal cords and inferiorly by tracheal rings

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with glottic carcinoma is found to have lateral extension of the tumor on CT scan. The radiologist notes involvement of a fat-filled laryngeal space that lies lateral to the ventricle and is continuous with the pre-epiglottic space. Which of the following best describes this space and its anatomical boundaries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paraglottic space; bounded laterally by thyroid cartilage and medially by quadrangular membrane

 

 

  • The paraglottic space is a potential fat-containing space in the lateral part of the larynx, and plays a critical role in the spread of laryngeal cancers.
  • It is bounded by:
    • Laterally: Thyroid cartilage
    • Inferomedially: Conus elasticus
    • Medially: Quadrangular membrane and the laryngeal ventricle
    • Posteriorly: Mucosa of the pyriform fossa
  • It is continuous with the pre-epiglottic space, facilitating tumor extension from the glottis/supraglottis to the neck.
  • Tumors invading the paraglottic space can present externally in the neck, especially through the cricothyroid membrane.

 

Other Options:


Other A. Pre-epiglottic space; bounded laterally by pyriform sinus and medially by epiglottis: Incorrect. The pre-epiglottic space lies anterior to the epiglottis, not lateral.

Other C. Retropharyngeal space; located posterior to pharynx and thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. The retropharyngeal space lies posterior to the pharynx and is not related to glottic extension.

Other D. Infraglottic space; bounded superiorly by the vocal cords and inferiorly by tracheal rings: Incorrect. The infraglottic space lies below the vocal cords and does not communicate with the ventricle or quadrangular membrane.

 

Educational Objective:


The paraglottic space lies lateral to the laryngeal ventricle and facilitates lateral tumor spread, bounded by the thyroid cartilage laterally and quadrangular membrane medially.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Paraglottic space
Pre-epiglottic space
Retropharyngeal space
Vallecular fossa

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with a 2-month history of progressive hoarseness and occasional dysphagia. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a supraglottic mass involving the epiglottis. Imaging shows infiltration into a fat-filled space between the epiglottis, hyoid bone, and thyroid cartilage. Which of the following anatomical spaces is most likely involved by the carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pre-epiglottic space


The pre-epiglottic space (of Boyer) lies between the epiglottis (posteriorly), thyrohyoid membrane (anteriorly), and hyoepiglottic ligament (superiorly). It contains fat, and is a known route of tumor spread from supraglottic carcinomas, especially epiglottic or base of tongue cancers. Pits on the epiglottic surface facilitate deep tissue invasion into this space.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraglottic space: Incorrect. This space is located lateral to the ventricle of the larynx, between the thyroid cartilage and the laryngeal mucosa, and is more commonly involved in glottic and subglottic tumors, not primarily in epiglottic lesions.

 

Option C. Retropharyngeal space: Incorrect. This space lies posterior to the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, and is a potential path for deep neck infections or metastatic lymph nodes, not primary supraglottic cancer spread.

 

OptionD. Vallecular fossa: Incorrect. Vallecula is the depression between the base of tongue and anterior surface of the epiglottis. While it may be involved secondarily, it is not the fat-filled space invaded through the deep surface of the epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective:


The pre-epiglottic space, a fat-filled area between the epiglottis, hyoid, and thyroid cartilage, is commonly invaded by supraglottic and base-of-tongue carcinomas.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve
Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle
Cricothyroid joint
Aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: A 40-year-old professional singer presents with difficulty in hitting high-pitched notes and complains of mild vocal fatigue. Examination reveals no vocal cord paralysis. Laryngoscopic evaluation is unremarkable. Injury to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid joint

 


The cricothyroid joint is formed by the articulation of the inferior cornu of the thyroid cartilage with the posterolateral part of the cricoid cartilage. It allows tilting movement of the thyroid cartilage, controlled by the cricothyroid muscle (originating from cricoid and inserting into thyroid). This tenses the vocal cords, which is essential for producing high-pitched sounds. Dysfunction or trauma to this joint can impair vocal pitch modulation, especially in singers or voice professionals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. This nerve innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except cricothyroid). Its injury causes vocal cord paralysis, hoarseness, or breathy voice, but not isolated loss of pitch control.

 

Option B. Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle: Incorrect. This is the only abductor of the vocal cords. Its dysfunction causes airway obstruction, not issues with pitch or phonation alone.

 

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold: Incorrect. It forms part of the laryngeal inlet and plays a role in airway protection, not in tensioning of vocal cords or pitch regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

The cricothyroid joint, moved by the cricothyroid muscle, adjusts vocal cord tension and is crucial for pitch modulation, especially in professional voice users.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Vocal processes of arytenoids provide insertion for all intrinsic laryngeal muscles
Cricoarytenoid joint allows only rotatory movement of arytenoids
Muscular processes of arytenoids help in movement of vocal cords via intrinsic muscles
Cuneiform cartilages lie on the apex of arytenoids and assist vocal cord movement

questions.text: A 62-year-old man undergoes prolonged endotracheal intubation for mechanical ventilation. After extubation, he presents with hoarseness and stridor. Laryngoscopic examination reveals limited movement of the vocal cords, and bilateral arytenoid edema is noted. Which of the following statements best explains the functional anatomy affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscular processes of arytenoids help in movement of vocal cords via intrinsic muscles

 

 

The muscular process of the arytenoid projects posterolaterally and serves as the insertion point for several intrinsic laryngeal muscles, including the posterior cricoarytenoid and lateral cricoarytenoid muscles, which abduct and adduct the vocal cords respectively. Limited arytenoid movement post-intubation can lead to impaired vocal cord motion and symptoms like hoarseness or stridor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal processes of arytenoids provide insertion for all intrinsic laryngeal muscles: Incorrect. The vocal process serves as the anterior attachment point for the vocal ligament, not for all intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

 

Option B. Cricoarytenoid joint allows only rotatory movement of arytenoids: Incorrect. The cricoarytenoid joint is a synovial joint allowing both rotatory and gliding movements, essential for fine-tuned vocal cord positioning.

 

Option D. Cuneiform cartilages lie on the apex of arytenoids and assist vocal cord movement: Incorrect. The corniculate cartilages lie on the apex of arytenoids. The cuneiform cartilages lie above the corniculates and do not directly assist in vocal cord movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscular processes of arytenoids anchor intrinsic laryngeal muscles and play a critical role in vocal cord movement via the cricoarytenoid joint.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Corniculate cartilage
Cuneiform cartilage
Cricoid cartilage
Epiglottis

questions.text: A 72-year-old man undergoes a chest X-ray after a brief episode of choking. The radiologist notes calcified structures in the neck area and suggests further evaluation to rule out a foreign body. You suspect the calcification may be age-related. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricoid cartilage

 


The cricoid cartilage is made of hyaline cartilage, which undergoes ossification later in life, especially in the elderly. This can be seen as calcified areas on X-ray, which may mimic foreign bodies. Cricoid, along with thyroid and most of the arytenoid cartilage (except apex), is subject to such ossification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corniculate cartilage: Incorrect. Corniculate cartilage is elastic, not hyaline. It does not ossify, and thus is not a cause of calcification on imaging.

 

Option B. Cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. Like the corniculate, the cuneiform cartilage is also elastic, and does not undergo ossification, so it won't appear calcified on X-ray.

 

Option D. Epiglottis: Incorrect. The epiglottis is elastic cartilage, which remains flexible and does not ossify, hence it does not lead to radiological confusion in older adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyaline cartilages of the larynx—thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid (except apex)—can ossify with age and may mimic foreign bodies on X-rays in elderly patients.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a penetrating neck injury just above the thyroid cartilage. He has a hoarse voice but no airway compromise. On examination, there is tenderness at the level of the Adam’s apple and loss of sensation above the vocal cords on the affected side. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

 

 

This nerve pierces the thyrohyoid membrane along with superior laryngeal vessels, just above the thyroid cartilage. It provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords (supraglottic larynx). Injury here causes loss of sensation above the glottis and risk of aspiration, while voice may be slightly affected due to impaired cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. This nerve supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles (except cricothyroid) and sensory below the vocal cords. Injury causes hoarseness, but it enters the larynx from below, not through the thyrohyoid membrane.

 

Option C. External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. It supplies the cricothyroid muscle (tenses vocal cords). Its injury causes monotonous voice due to inability to modulate pitch but does not cause sensory loss above the cords. It travels near the superior thyroid artery, not through the thyrohyoid membrane.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. It innervates the posterior third of the tongue, pharynx, and contributes to the gag reflex. It does not pass through the thyrohyoid membrane or innervate the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:


The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve pierces the thyrohyoid membrane and provides sensation above the vocal cords; injury leads to supraglottic sensory loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: True vocal cord
Aryepiglottic fold
Laryngeal saccule
Cricothyroid membrane

questions.text: A 45-year-old glassblower presents with a painless, compressible swelling in the neck that enlarges when he blows forcefully through his mouth and reduces on relaxation. On laryngoscopic examination, an air-filled outpouching is seen arising from the laryngeal ventricle. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely involved in the origin of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal saccule

 

 

The laryngeal saccule is a blind-ending pouch extending from the laryngeal ventricle between the false vocal cord (vestibular fold) above and true vocal cord below. It contains mucous glands that lubricate the vocal cords. Overuse of expiratory force (e.g., in glassblowers) may cause its distension, forming an air-filled laryngocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True vocal cord: Incorrect. While the true vocal cords lie below the ventricle, they are not the origin of laryngocele. They do not contain mucous glands.

 

Option B. Aryepiglottic fold: Incorrect. This is the upper border of the quadrangular membrane and does not form the floor or medial wall of the ventricle or give rise to the saccule.

 

Option D. Cricothyroid membrane: Incorrect. This membrane lies below the glottis, between the cricoid and thyroid cartilages. It is not related to the ventricle or saccule, hence not the site of laryngocele origin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule, which arises from the laryngeal ventricle between the false and true vocal cords.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Spasmodic dysphonia
Dysphonia plica ventricularis
Vocal cord polyp
Laryngeal papillomatosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a hoarse and strained voice. Laryngoscopic examination reveals that his true vocal cords are mobile and structurally normal, but there is excessive approximation of the false vocal cords during phonation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphonia plica ventricularis

 

 

This condition refers to abnormal voice production using the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) instead of the true cords. It results in a strained, low-pitched, or hoarse voice and is termed "dysphonia plica ventricularis."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spasmodic dysphonia: Incorrect. This is a neurologic disorder causing involuntary spasms of the laryngeal muscles during speech, but not specifically due to false cord approximation.

 

Option C. Vocal cord polyp: Incorrect. Polyps are structural lesions on the true vocal cords, often due to vocal abuse, and present as hoarseness, but not due to false cord use.

 

Option D. Laryngeal papillomatosis: Incorrect. This is caused by HPV infection, presenting with multiple papillomas on the laryngeal surface, typically the true cords, and does not involve false cord phonation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysphonia plica ventricularis is a voice disorder caused by phonation using false vocal cords instead of true vocal cords.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Thyrohyoid membrane
Cricothyroid membrane
Tracheal rings
Cricovocal ligament

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe upper airway obstruction following peanut aspiration. Attempts at orotracheal intubation fail. The decision is made to perform an emergency cricothyrotomy. Through which of the following structures is the airway most safely accessed in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroid membrane

 

 

The cricothyroid membrane, also known as the anterior thickened part of the cricovocal membrane, is the preferred site for emergency cricothyrotomy. It lies between the thyroid cartilage above and the cricoid cartilage below, providing a quick and relatively avascular entry to the airway in life-threatening obstructions.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyrohyoid membrane: Incorrect. This membrane lies above the thyroid cartilage, between it and the hyoid bone. It is not used for airway access, and contains vessels and nerves, such as the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. Tracheal rings: Incorrect. Tracheostomy is performed through tracheal rings, usually below the cricoid cartilage, but this takes longer and is not preferred in emergencies when airway access is urgently needed.

 

Option D. Cricovocal ligament: Incorrect. This is another term referring to the conus elasticus or part of the membrane between cricoid and vocal ligament, but the term is non-specific and does not indicate the site used in emergency airway access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid membrane is the site of choice for emergency cricothyrotomy due to its accessibility and location between the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Branchial cyst
Laryngocele
Thyroglossal duct cyst
Reactive cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A 40-year-old glass-blower presents with a soft, compressible neck swelling on the left side that enlarges during coughing and Valsalva maneuver. On compression, the swelling decreases in size and a hissing sound is heard from the throat. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngocele

 

 

A laryngocele is an air-filled cystic dilation of the laryngeal saccule, which may remain internal or extend externally through the thyrohyoid membrane. It is associated with activities that increase intralaryngeal pressure (e.g., glass-blowing). The Bryce sign (hissing sound on compression) is classic. It enlarges on Valsalva maneuver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Incorrect. This is a fluid-filled congenital lesion located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It does not change in size with Valsalva or produce air sounds.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal duct cyst: Incorrect. This congenital cyst is found in the midline of the neck and moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion—not with Valsalva. No hissing sound is associated.

 

Option D. Reactive cervical lymphadenopathy: Incorrect. This appears as a firm, tender or non-tender swelling depending on etiology. It does not change with pressure or Valsalva, and no air sound is produced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngocele is an air-filled dilatation of the laryngeal saccule that may herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and present as a compressible neck swelling that enlarges with Valsalva and produces a hissing sound on compression (Bryce sign).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282
